descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course is the second part in a four-course introductory biology sequence. You will learn fundamental principles in Human Physiology, covering all the major organ systems including Cardiovascular, Respiratory, Neural/Endocrine, Muscular, Renal/Digestive, Immune systems. You will also learn how different organ systems are structurally and functionally connected together to co-ordinate body functions. This course fulfills the requirements for medical, dental, and other professional school programs.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
At the end of this course, students will be able to:
? Define physiology
? Describe the anatomy and functions of the categories of epithelia, parts of a neuron, muscles, the heart, the blood, the lungs, the kidney, the digestive system, the immune system, the endocrine system
? Create a map to compare simple diffusion, protein-mediated transport
? Explain how cascades and signal amplification play a role in signal transduction
? Describe the different types of receptors for somatic and special senses.
? Compare and contrast the anatomy and chemical communication of the sympathetic and parasympathetic branches.
? Explain how receptors convert physical stimuli into electrical signals using the following terms: transduction, threshold, adequate stimulus, receptive field, receptor potential
? Analyze the molecular events of excitation-contraction coupling and the contractile cycle.
? Interpret the pressure changes that occur during the cardiac cycle and their relationship to flow through the heart and blood vessels.
? Explain what creates blood pressure and how blood pressure changes as blood flows through the systemic circulation.
? Analzye how pressures and lung volumes change during normal breathing, and how that affects air flow in the respiratory system.
? Describe all the factors that influence gas exchange between the atmosphere and arterial blood
? Explain the filtration barriers between the blood and the lumen of the nephron, and explain how they can be modified to control filtration.
? Describe and differentiate between different types of primary lymphoid tissues and secondary lymphoid tissues.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: The class will be mostly lecture, with class participation required in the form of answering and asking questions. There will be one in-class presentation required.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Grades will be based on a midterm exam, final exam, reading quizzes, class participation, and an in-class presentation.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: Textbook: Human Physiology, 7th ed. By Dee Unglaub Silverthorn.
